description: Adapted from the popular storybooks of the same name by Yutaka Hara, Kaiketsu Zorori follows the adventures of a scheming fox named Zorori, who is determined to become the King of Pranks with his very own castle and beautiful bride.  Although Zorori is notorious for his pranks and tricks, his conniving plots often backfire and end up helping his targets, and despite appearing to be villainous and immoral, he is actually caring and sentimental.  Nevertheless, Zorori has the wits, intelligence, and dexterity to always find a solution out of the most hopeless of situations.  Travelling with a pair of twin boar bandits, Ishishi and Noshishi, he continues on his journey to make his deceased mother proud.

tags.name: Animals
tags.description: Prominently features animal characters in a leading role.

tags.name: Anti-Hero
tags.description: Features a protagonist who lacks conventional heroic attributes and may be considered a borderline villain.

tags.name: Anthropomorphism

tags.name: Twins
tags.description: Prominently features two or more siblings that were born at one birth.

tags.name: Fugitive
tags.description: Prominently features a character evading capture by an individual or organization.

tags.name: Dinosaurs
tags.description: Prominently features Dinosaurs, prehistoric reptiles that went extinct millions of years ago.

tags.name: Musical Theater
tags.description: Features a performance that combines songs, spoken dialogue, acting, and dance.

node.description:
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/吉田玲子) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reiko_Yoshida)

Yoshida has written and supervised numerous scripts for anime series, live-action dramas and films. Her major works include [Kaleido Star](https://anilist.co/anime/427), [Aria](https://anilist.co/anime/477), [Maria-sama ga Miteru](https://anilist.co/anime/158), [D.Gray-man](https://anilist.co/anime/1482), [K-On!](https://anilist.co/anime/5680), [Bakuman](https://anilist.co/anime/7674) and [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131). In more recent works, she has supervised the screenplays for [Majestic Prince](https://anilist.co/anime/15863), [Non Non Biyori](https://anilist.co/anime/17549), [A Town Where You Live](https://anilist.co/anime/17741), [Tamako Market](https://anilist.co/anime/16417), [Yowamushi Pedal](https://anilist.co/anime/18179) and [Castle Town Dandelion](https://anilist.co/anime/20951). In films, she wrote the screenplay for Ghibli's [The Cat Returns](https://anilist.co/anime/597), the original films that would make up [Digimon: The Movie](https://anilist.co/anime/2961), Kyoto Animation’s hit anime film [A Silent Voice](https://anilist.co/anime/20954), and the film adaptations of Osamu Tezuka's [Buddha](https://anilist.co/anime/7014), the last one's [second film](https://anilist.co/anime/20500) was given a stamp of approval by the Dalai Lama.

Among her works, she was recognized for Best Screenplay/Original Work for [Girls und Panzer](https://anilist.co/anime/14131) at the Tokyo Anime Award Festival in 2014, and she won another Best Screenplay/Original Work award in 2017. In 2018, she wrote the screenplay for [Violet Evergarden](https://anilist.co/anime/21827) which aired on TV in Japan and is licensed by Netflix.

Yoshida also wrote the story for the manga series [Tokyo Mew Mew](https://anilist.co/manga/30554).

(Source: Wikipedia)

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/kenokun)

Kouhei attended Tokyo National University of Fine Arts and Music (Music Faculty, Composition Department), studying under Tomojirou Ikenouchi and other professors. He worked for three consecutive years at Victor Music Industries after he graduated from the University. He attended Berklee College of Music for two years after he left Victor Music Industries. After returning to Japan, Kouhei started his activities as a composer.

Though Kouhei had been playing at the hotel at first, he was requested to compose an insert song for "Arcadia of My Youth: Endless Orbit SSX", a 1982 TV anime, and it became his first work as a composer. Afterwards, he handled some more compositions of insert songs, this time for the Super Sentai series and he also did the composition of the background music for a TV anime, Konpora Kid, in 1985.

Notably, the score for [Top wo Nerae! Gunbuster](https://anilist.co/anime/949/) made his name and talent very famous among anime fans, and is recognized as one of his most important works. He also handled the composition of [Top wo Nerae 2! Diebuster](https://anilist.co/anime/1002/) and showed a peculiar arrangement, which he added to his previous 17-year-old work. Another of his most important work is often said to be [Yuusha-Ou GaoGaiGar](https://anilist.co/anime/890/), and the [sequel](https://anilist.co/anime/1382/) following it.

In 2002, he won the first Tokyo Anime Award for Best Music for his work on [Overman King Gainer](https://anilist.co/anime/1792/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/fusatora2828) | [Blog](https://ameblo.jp/mangetsuhakase)

While attending Waseda University, Mochizuki became interested in animation and he joined the Waseda University Animation Association. In 1981, he began working for Ajia-do Animation Works. Mochizuki made his debut one year later when he acted as production director of the 1982 series Tokimeki Tonight. He went on to direct several of the magical girl series, including Magical Angel Creamy Mami. In 1986, he moved up to chief director with Hikari no Densetsu.

Mochizuki became known from the early 1990s as director of Ranma ½, Kimagure Orange Road and the Studio Ghibli TV movie Ocean Waves, he is also known for having directed Twin Spica, Zettai Shounen, the acclaimed World Masterpiece Theater series Porphy no Nagai Tabi. More recently he directed the noitaminA series House of Five Leaves in 2010 and Battery in 2016.

He currently divides his time between directing, writing scripts and acting as a series coordinator for various shows.

Married to [Masako Gotou](https://anilist.co/staff/153654/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/福冨博) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hiroshi_Fukutomi)

Originating from [Shin-Ei Animation](https://anilist.co/studio/247/)

Married to animator [Kazuko Fukutomi](https://anilist.co/staff/157057/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/nishiki_hiroshi)

He is unilaterally liked by [Kunihiko Ikuhara](https://anilist.co/staff/100082/Kunihiko-Ikuhara). His work on [Revolutionary Girl Utena](https://anilist.co/anime/440/Revolutionary-Girl-Utena/) storyboards were outright claimed to be the "closest to his own style" , in principle, by Ikuhara himself.

His work on [Revolutionary Girl Utena](https://anilist.co/anime/440/Revolutionary-Girl-Utena/) storyboards were outright claimed to be the "closest to his own style" , in principle, by Ikuhara himself.

__[Profile (Imagine)](https://www.imagine-music.co.jp/artist/index/10)__

__Birthplace:__ Tokyo, Japan

__Takayuki Negishi__ is a Japanese guitarist, composer, arranger and music producer affiliated with Imagine Music, better known for his composition work on several anime, such as; the hit magical girl TV series Cardcaptor Sakura, Tokyo Mew Mew and Mnemosyne. He began working in the industry as a synthesizer operator in 1983, before he later became a composer. He also produces music for several  artists like Mariko Nagai and Hiroko Moriguchi.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Sunma47) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/三間雅文)

One of the industry's most prolific sound directors, having worked on more than 300 productions.

After having graduated college, Mima joined Magic Capsule, a sound production company ran by his relative [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062/). In 1986, he debuted as a sound director on [MD Geist](https://anilist.co/anime/1285/MD-Geist/). He left Magic Capsule in 1996, and later joined Techno Sound. In 2004, he became the studio's representative director.

Affiliated with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/).

Came to prominence as an assistant director on numerous films in the '80s and '90s.

Originating from [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/).

_Note: Not to be confused with either the [Duel Masters character designer](https://anilist.co/staff/185645/) or the [studio coordinator](https://anilist.co/staff/172956/)._

_Note: Not to be confused with the [painter](https://anilist.co/staff/194863/)._

Affiliated with Atelier Platz.
